priority_legend.nice_to_ask: Only if condition matches AND time allows.

meta.green_note: Questions marked green: true are Patrycja's top picks — at least one green question per section must be included.

pre_call_opener.label: Pre-Call Opener
pre_call_opener.instruction: Pick exactly 1. Choose the health-signal variant if LinkedIn shows fitness/sport/health content. Otherwise choose from the no-signal set.

questions.text: I saw you're into [running / cycling / CrossFit] — do you use any specific supplements or protocols to keep your performance up? I'm genuinely curious what works for people at your pace.
questions.why: Creates peer-to-peer energy. Bridges naturally to team-level questions.

questions.text: You clearly invest in your own performance — do you think about your team's physical baseline the same way, or is that a separate conversation entirely?
questions.why: Bridges personal health to team-level thinking.

questions.text: Do you personally take any supplements or follow any protocols to stay sharp during intense work periods — or is that not really your thing?
questions.why: Low-pressure yes/no entry point.

questions.text: How do you personally deal with long days and back-to-back weeks — anything specific that helps you recover or stay focused?
questions.why: Gets at personal coping patterns naturally.

questions.text: When you have a stretch of really hard weeks — what's the first thing that suffers for you personally? Sleep, focus, energy, exercise?
questions.why: Opens the 'health is the first compromise' theme gently.

ambition_paradox.label: The Ambition Paradox
ambition_paradox.instruction: Pick 1-2. Let them describe the gap in their own language. Silence or 'I don't know' is itself a signal.

questions.text: When the company goes through a really intense sprint — a big launch, fundraise, tight deadline — what's the first thing you notice people cutting corners on?
questions.why: Listen for: sleep, exercise, eating, skipping breaks. Don't suggest answers.

questions.text: Do you ever feel like there's a gap between how ambitious your team is and what they can actually sustain physically over time?
questions.why: Direct test of the paradox. If yes — dig deep.

questions.text: Have you ever lost someone good — not because they left for another job, but because they just burned out and couldn't keep up anymore?
questions.why: Connects the paradox to real, personal cost.

questions.text: When you walk around the office in the afternoon — say around 3 PM — what does the energy actually look like (compared to morning)? What do you see?
questions.why: Gets behavioral observation, not opinion.

opening.label: Opening
opening.instruction: Pick exactly 1. Choose based on culture_type from enriched data.

questions.text: What's the biggest bottleneck to your team's output right now?
questions.why: Matches goal-oriented culture — speaks their language of output and speed.

questions.text: What's the biggest people challenge you're dealing with as you scale?
questions.why: Matches people-oriented culture — leads with the human dimension.

questions.text: What are your top 3 priorities this quarter — and which one feels most at risk?
questions.why: Safe default when culture type is ambiguous — surfaces their actual frame.

output_and_capacity.label: Output & Capacity Discovery
output_and_capacity.instruction: Pick 1-2. Prioritize GREEN questions. At least one GREEN must be included.

questions.text: When your team has a rough afternoon — low energy, hard to focus — what do you usually attribute that to?
questions.why: Gets root cause attribution without leading.

questions.text: Have you ever tried to measure how many hours of real deep work your team actually gets per day — not hours at desk, but real focused output?
questions.why: Direct yes/no — important to know if they've even framed this.

questions.text: Is increasing your team's capacity — getting more output without adding headcount — something you're actively trying to solve right now?
questions.why: Validates whether capacity is a live priority.

questions.text: Walk me through a recent week where the team was really on — what made it work?
questions.why: Gets past behavior, not hypothesis.

questions.text: Tell me about the last time a key person on your team was visibly off their game. What did you attribute it to?
questions.why: Surfaces real attribution patterns.

questions.text: How do you currently think about the difference between your team being busy versus genuinely productive?
questions.why: Probes if they've operationalized this distinction.

questions.text: Do you notice a difference in the quality of work that comes out in the morning versus late afternoon? Is it obvious or subtle?
questions.why: Tests whether they've noticed output quality decline across the day.

questions.text: Is the afternoon energy drop something you've tried to solve, or something you've accepted as part of how offices work?
questions.why: Use if they've already mentioned energy or output patterns.

questions.text: If you could get one extra hour of focused output per person per day without adding headcount — what would you do with that capacity?
questions.why: Use only after the problem is established — reveals ambition and opportunity size.

questions.text: Have you ever noticed that your highest performers tend to manage their health most deliberately — sleep, exercise, diet? Or is it random?
questions.why: Tests whether they've connected performance to health themselves.

benefits_and_people.label: Benefits & People Investment
benefits_and_people.instruction: Pick 1-2. Prioritize GREEN questions. At least one GREEN must be included. Apply conditional questions based on known benefits data.

questions.text: Walk me through what you currently offer your team in terms of perks and benefits. What was the last thing you added?
questions.why: Gets current state and recency.

questions.text: Tell me about the last benefit you added — what made you add it, and how did you know if it worked?
questions.why: Reveals decision trigger and success metrics.

questions.text: Which benefits do your people actually talk about — and which ones do you suspect they never use?
questions.why: Surfaces utilization reality.

questions.text: If you had to cut 20% of your people budget tomorrow, what stays and what goes — and why?
questions.why: Reveals true priority stack.

questions.text: How do you personally think about ROI on people investments — employee satisfaction, retention, or something more tied to output?
questions.why: Frames their mental model for evaluation.

questions.text: Do you feel like the benefits you currently offer are making a difference in how your team feels at work?
questions.why: Honest gap question — surfaces dissatisfaction without leading.

questions.text: You're already investing in food for the team — beyond that, what do people rely on to stay sharp through the afternoon?
questions.why: Use only if benefits include catered lunch or food perks.

questions.text: With the wellness stipend you offer — do you have any sense of what people are actually spending it on?
questions.why: Use only if a wellness stipend or LSA exists in benefits.

purchase_process.label: Purchase Process
purchase_process.instruction: Pick exactly 1. Use the thin-benefits variant if benefits stack is minimal or unknown.

questions.text: Tell me about the last benefit or tool you bought for the team — what was the process, and what did it cost per person per month?
questions.why: Use when benefits stack is thin or unknown — surfaces buying behavior from scratch.

questions.text: What was the last thing you tried that didn't work? What killed it — adoption, cost, fit?
questions.why: Surfaces veto patterns — use when they have an existing benefits stack to reference.

questions.text: Tell me about a benefit you recently rejected. What was the actual deal-killer?
questions.why: Gets veto criteria from real past decisions.

wellness_competitor.label: Wellness Competitor Check
wellness_competitor.instruction: Pick exactly 1. Conditional on whether a wellness competitor was detected in benefits.

questions.text: You have [competitor name] in place — how are employees actually engaging with it day-to-day?
questions.why: Opens honest conversation about utilization of existing wellness tool.

questions.text: Are you seeing any patterns around burnout, energy, or focus issues with the team?
questions.why: Entry point for wellness conversation when no competitor is present.

app_discovery.label: App Discovery — Founder Perspective
app_discovery.instruction: Pick 1-2. Frame as: 'we're figuring out what to build' — not 'here's what we're building.' At least one GREEN must be included.

questions.text: What health or wellness apps do you currently use — even occasionally? Which one have you actually stuck with longest, and what made it different?
questions.why: Gets current behavior and retention drivers from lived experience.

questions.text: If you had a dashboard showing how your team is doing health-wise — sleep quality, energy trends, focus patterns — would you actually look at it? What would you do with it?
questions.why: Tests demand for team-level health data before we build it.

questions.text: What's the line for you between 'useful insight into my team's wellbeing' and 'invasive surveillance'? Where does it flip?
questions.why: Critical privacy boundary mapping — do not assume.

questions.text: What does 'proving this is working' look like to you — employee feedback survey, usage data, or something you'd actually see in their output?
questions.why: Defines success metrics they'd trust.

questions.text: If an AI could look at your team's health data and give you a weekly signal — 'your team is running low, consider X' — would you trust that? What would make you trust it?
questions.why: Tests AI-guided recommendations for executives.

questions.text: What's the most useful notification you've ever received from any app — one that actually made you do something differently?
questions.why: Gets at effective nudge design.

stress_tests.label: Stress Tests — Commitment & Reality Checks
stress_tests.instruction: Pick 0-1. Use only in second meetings or when you sense they're being politely positive but not genuinely committed.

questions.text: What are you doing right now to solve the focus/energy problem? If nothing — why hasn't it become a priority yet?
questions.why: Tests urgency vs. lip service.

questions.text: Imagine we sign a contract today. What's the most likely thing that causes this to fail in your specific office environment?
questions.why: Surfaces real objections disguised as support.

questions.text: Tell me about a benefit you recently rejected. What was the actual deal-killer?
questions.why: Gets veto criteria from real past decisions.
